Replacement for Robo Y Tensioner. Original size and one that is beefed up a little since mine broke from over tightening the tension screw. Print solid fill in PLA. May have to sand sides a little, it's a tight fit.
It is installed under the hot bed. Remove the screw on the front of the support rails and the tensioner will slide out. Remove cable and attach new tensioner.

description.text: My MakerBot's Y-belt sometimes slips loose of the clip provided in the kit, so I designed a fix for it. This hasn't been tested in situ yet, but I'm pretty confident that the underhang design will put the belt slipping issue to bed. Tuck the hook under the y-stage with the belt between the main bar and the ribs, and the screw should now be effectively applying pressure at both ends of the belt, as well as physically blocking it from moving down. Getting that hole to print is annoying but I got it right once in my pre-tests...

title: Demo case with tapered holding mechanism
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I developed some microwells for use in my day job ( http://tinyurl.com/6bm6bth if anyone's interested), and when I am e.g. presenting a poster it's useful to have some examples to show people what I am working on. I made this demo case a couple of years back to hold them and keep dust out etc. I am posting it here as someone asked about strategies for fitting parts together - in this case I have tapered the interface between the two parts (look closely at the join between the wide and narrow sections of the insert, and the corresponding surfaces on the case), and it clicks together nicely. IIRC I put either 0.5 or 1.0 mm allowance in the direction of travel (not normal to the surface), which has worked out perfectly and allowed for wear over the last couple of years. The nice thing about this strategy is that you slide it in until it fits right, so as long as you can handle a bit of +/- in the one axis, it's very tolerant of imperfections in the print. Probably zero allowance would have been OK hot off the printer, but after many cycles of opening and closing it has worn down a bit - it still works perfectly, but only because I left that allowance. It was printed on a Stratasys Dimension printer.

May require some Meshlab-fu to make it printable. Apologies but I am not sure where the original .aoi files are, I will post them if I can find them (along with a photo of the one I made). Consider orientation when printing as excessive stair-stepping on the inclined planes of the interface will cause problems.

I found that with all my Bezier messing around, I needed some simple balance.
This thing is a simple yin/yang symbol.  
You can print it as is, although to make it look good in a single color, there is some slight separation of the two halves.  Still very yin/yang ish.  It does NOT use any Bezier curves!  Although, I'm sure you could.
Really it was an experiment in coloring with OpenScad.  It turns out that OpenScad will still try to apply color to the parts that have been removed.
For this thing, it prints as two halves of the same thing, with one rotated 180 degrees around the z-axis.  Of course it is parameterized, so you can print it any size you want.  You just have to select the greater radius, and the radius of the 'dots'.  I'm sure interesting variants can be made, but there's the basic form.

1) Print one
2) Stare at it
3) Be at peace
4) Rejoice!

comments.author: RalphVigg

comments.text: The printer is a good design. The auto leveling works great. That being said I did have a few issues, however most of them have been addressed by installing solutions others have designed. Most of the upgrades I found on Thingiverse. For the money I would say it's a good value.

Just purchased the ROBO 3D R1.  Make sure you are getting the latest printer and to be honest there is nothing yet that I have had to modify other than software settings to get a great print.  The R1 addressed multiple issues that the previous model had.  One thing to keep in mind is if you are going to print PLA mostly, you are going to want to install/print an oiler (seasoner) before the extruder.  This will alleviate any friction issues and make the printer that much better.

title: Ecig Coil Jig, The RBA Awakens

description.text:
A simple jig for making coils for your RBA, made for various sizes, 2mm, 2.5mm and 3mm, if you would like any more sizes remix it or tell me in the comments.
You will need a rod or a drill bit of the appropriate metric size for this to work, sorry USA I don't have any imperial sizes to test this. The bottom section has a tight fit to hold the drill bit, make sure you can print this accurately. Edit: added new bottom section designs based on the skywaker Lightsaber!! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tdw46uc3MRY

Print upright, no support. layer height 0.15mm (for the top section), 0.2mm for the bottom section will suffice, 20% infill, 2 perimeter shell min.
Choose between the original bottom and the new lightsaber bottom.

description.text:
A 3D printable model rocket for every one to use! If you wish to donate, go to my "Cults3d" profile: https://cults3d.com/en/users/Trystan
*More images coming soon! To make this rocket you will also need to purchase the following materials: 1x 18" Nylon Parachute
https://www.allrocketengines.ca/Build/Parachutes/Nylon-Red-18 1x 24mm Motor Holder
https://www.allrocketengines.ca/Build/Motor-Mounts/BT-55-24 1x Elastic Shock Cord
https://www.allrocketengines.ca/Build/Shock-Cords/Ribbon 1x Wadding Paper Pack
https://www.allrocketengines.ca/Accessories/EstesWadding Some D12-5 or D12-3 Rocket Engines
https://www.allrocketengines.ca/D/D12-5
https://www.allrocketengines.ca/D/D12-3 Optional Materials: Launch Pad WITH Maxi Rods:
https://www.allrocketengines.ca/Launch-Equipment/Pads/Porta-Pad?cPath=19_150
https://www.allrocketengines.ca/Launch-Equipment/Rods/316 Remote Ignition System:
https://www.allrocketengines.ca/Launch-Equipment/Controllers/Electron-Beam?cPath=19_149

BUILD INSTRUCTIONS: Step 1: Print all the required parts (Nose cone, Body, Fin section)
(The guiding holes are optional, but recommended. Also the writing may require supports, but they are a hassle to remove if used.) Step 2: Glue the body to the fin section with epoxy or the equivalent Step 3: Glue the engine mount into the fin section, make sure the metal retainer is not glued down. (A rocket engine can be inserted in the mount during the drying process to prevent this) Step 4: Cut a 1.5' section of your elastic shock cord and glue it to both the inside of the nose cone and body. (Make sure that it is glued in a way that the nose cone and body can be joined) Step 5 (Optional): If the elastic shock cord snapped on your first launch repeat step 4 for extra strength. Step 6: Tie all the strands of the parachute in a "Girth Hitch" around
the mid-point of the elastic shock cord. (File includes 7, but only two are necessary) Step 7: Glue the guiding holes in the gap between two fins, one 1/2" down from the top of the body and one 1/2 above the bottom of the fin section. Step 8: That's it for the assembly! PRE-LAUNCH SET UP: Step 1: Insert 3 sheets of the wadding paper into the body. Step 2: Fold the nylon parachute tightly and insert it into the body. Step 3: Take all the loose strands of the parachute or elastic and also insert the into the body. Step 4: Close the body by joining the nose cone to it. (It is normal for the nose cone to be loose) Step 5: Insert the engine into the mount. Step 6: Insert the small igniter in the divot on the bottom of the engine and then also insert the white plug into the divot. Step 7: Place the guiding holes of your rocket into the guiding rod of the launch pad. Step 8: Connect the clips of your remote launch system and back up a safe distance. Step 9: Launch!

remixed_from.author: berryd
remixed_from.title: Airtripper Bowden Copy For MK7 Hobbed Shaft Collar

description.text:
My heavily modified airtripper extruder.  This is based on a few different items from here, including the 39:11 herringbone gears for the Wade's extruder, and of course the airtripper.  I've tried to include everything necessary to get this to work in the tarball.  This is designed to bolt in place of the original airtripper so long as you have enough room for the motor to be offset.  
UPDATE:  I have used this thing heavily since I uploaded it and it still works great.  I can easily change filament without removing anything except the hot-end hose (to ensure it feeds into the hot-end correctly).

Print it and put it together.  Pretty simple...except:  getting one of the nuts for the pinch wheel in place is a massive PITA.  I had to use a paper clip to slide it in.  I don't like this and have been meaning to fix it, but just haven't had the time nor inclination.  There are few things about design I would like to fix.  
The key part of this is the 5mm allen bolt which replaces the stepper shaft.  I found one at a local hardware store which was long enough.  I modified the large gear to accept a proper nut and used to two to pinch it in place.  I haven't had a slip yet, though I have ground up plenty of filament.  This bugger has some torque.  Manually feeding is nice since the large gear is exposed.  I don't recall the specifics on all of the vitamens but I can figure it out if someone needs me to do so (requires two of the small bearings for the airtripper).  I did abondon the shaft collar on the bowden clamp and went back to a nut under the knurled piece, which has worked quite well and allows easy removal.  
If anyone wants more details, I'll be happy to provide.  One of these days I'll get this thing where I want it, but for now, I'm pretty pleased with the performance.  
I'm using 708 for E steps.  
Edit:  I see there is a bit of interest, so I've added some photos.  The shaft is a partially threaded M5x55 allen head.  The extension bolts are M6x50.  I have washers between the body and stepper to offset, but your motor may not require this.  If you don't like it, simply extend the mounting boss tabs a tiny bit.  I've modified the small gear to take a standard (as in not-metric thread) 8-32 hex nut and allen lock.  The big gear takes a standard M5 nut, but use two to lock it in place--the spacers are designed to accomodate this.  The gear mesh can be adjusted on the stepper motor and if you need to service it, you will need to use this slop to remove and reinstall the large gear.  Make sure to put the pinch wheel bolts and nuts in place before you mount it, or you will hate your life.  It's very easy to feed filament up from the bottom with the pinch wheel in place.  Simply rotate the large gear up as you feed the filament in and it should slide right up through the top hole, with the knurled bowden holder removed.  Also note that there is a washer between the small bearing on the back side and the large gear.  Once again, if anyone needs any more information, I'll be happy to help.  Thanks for the interest.  I think I covered most people in my last iterations, so just assume inheritence, but if I forgot to give shout-outs to anyone's work that I based this on, please let me know.  
Edit:  Use SmallHerringBoneFinal_bigger_slot.stl to match the hardware I listed.

This includes the size of the small bearings (you need two rather than one), the skateboard bearing, the bolt that the pinch wheel pivots on, the other long linkage bolt (same ad pivot), and I think I used the specified bolts for the tensioners and just got springs from the hardware store.  I can try and itemize it but I'll probably make mistakes.....

You can't do that with a push in fitting. Some people feel that the push in connectors ability to spin is a great advantage. I don't agree. The rotation of the bowden tube at the effector's push in connector is all that is needed. It has been working for me without a hitch.  Thanks.

Comments like: "But you obviously like to rant on the RTFM bandwagon"...and..." can't believe that the community actually embraces scad knowing well that a lot of people use high end packages and would contribute greatly if the solids were available for easy use"...are whining.
Forgive my previous post about MeshLab...I meant Blender. You should be able to use Blender as an intermediary. It's free and will export to .3ds, .x3d, .obj, .fbx, and a few others. This should give you what you want. If you have problems in your other app, simplify the polygon first.

comments.text: A quick Google says you can import STL files into Solidworks.  Get OpenSCAD, compile & render (F6) the SCAD files, export to STL, then import into Solidworks and do whatever you like.
comments.author: wbrokow1

comments.text:
No, you can't do whatever you like. the .stl file cannot be measured or edited in any of these software packs. It might be possible to extract certain lines or curves to be used in building new geometry, but you cannot measure an .stl file in any of these packs.
pretty frustrating, I would even live with 2d drawings to recreate the geometry; if that was available. I can't believe that the community actually embraces scad knowing well that a lot of people use high end packages and would contribute greatly if the solids were available for easy use. Do you have the files available in any of the formats list or not?
comments.author: berryd

comments.text:
The community embraces SCAD because it is free, it is opensource, and it allows us to share parametric designs (things with adjustable parameters to customize for different sizes/needs). The STL is metric, fyi...you might need to adjust your project settings in your application of your choosing. A STL file is just a list of vertices, and any application that handles vertex models (which is pretty much all of them) should have no problem telling you the distance between two points, and so long as you're editing the model in the right mode, they should allow you easily move a vertex or group of vertices. Maybe you should use MeshLAB as an intermediary. Maybe you should consult the documentation that came with your modeling application.
Alternately, you can use OpenSCAD and intersect the model with a plane to create DXF slices, which you use in a 2d CAD program to get dimensions. Or, you could read the SCAD file (it is nothing more than a simple program after all) and get all the measurements since they are pretty explicitly stated....and you'll find that all the critical dimensions are whole numbers anyway (with the exception of nuts/bolt heads, and this is because faceted polygons are circumscribed).
To succinctly answer your question: I do not have the files in your listed formats, and I will not be providing them. Spend some time on Google rather than whining and you'll solve your own problem. DIY means 'do it yourself'. There are plenty of great (and arguably better) extruder designs on this site, created by people who may be more patient than I am...but I am not going to hold your hand.
comments.author: wbrokow1

comments.text:

Parasolids ACIS, .sat or .x_t format is ok too.

comments.author: wbrokow1

comments.text: Why?  OpenSCAD is free and likely available for the platform of your choosing, and you can export to STL from the SCAD files.  Most open source modeling programs will accept STL files, and you should be able to find one to get it into a format that works for you.  OBJ is a pretty standard format...

https://www.etsy.com/uk/listing/201954267/totoro-cookie-cutter?ref=sr_gallery_1&ga_search_query=totoro+cookie+cutter&ga_order=most_relevant&ga_ship_to=GB&ga_ref=auto1&ga_search_type=all&ga_view_type=gallery

comments.text:
Dear TechDante,
Thank you for so much for making this cookie cutter. It took close to 3 hours to make, but the end product is beautiful to look at, very fine details, etc. I tried making cookies with it the next day, and had a problem, though. Someone else has mentioned it, but the outline (rim) is very high. It is 9 mm higher than the pattern imprint portion. That's over a third of an inch. It means that if your cookie dough is less than 9 mm, you get no imprint at all, and your cookie just has the outer shape of a totoro, and no features. But if you make the dough very thick, you don't get as many cookies, and they take longer to bake (cookies come out soft in center). I had difficulty in getting the dough thickness right, and maybe it was a problem with my sugar cookie recipe, but I was taking so much time in trying to get it right that the dough would get too soft, then get caught in the cookie cutter (not release from the form). Because the features are so fine, that meant running the cutter under hot water, and using a fine bristle brush to get all of the pieces of dough out each time I screwed up, even though I was also sticking the dough back into the refrigerator multiple times to try to prevent this. So please PLEASE reduce the height of the rim. A second thing I noticed was that a tiny amount of dough gets caught between the two layers of plastic making up the rim. It makes no difference to the way the cookie turns out, but I suppose it's possible that the trapped dough could harbor germs. You can't get it all out, and it subtracts from the beauty of the cookie cutter, too. If there were a way you could seal the two layers, that would also be an improvement. Anyway, these negative comments notwithstanding, I just love the appearance of the cookie cutter and thank you for sharing it!
comments.author: starsky

comments.text: hi  i designed the cookie cutter with a high rim mainly cos i like thick cookies ;) but also for trial and error with fining the perfect height. using an exacto (or other sharp blade) remove some of the  layers to get the desired height. please post the best height you use
comments.author: starsky

comments.text:
Dear TechDante,
I separated the imprint from the outline with a soldering iron, and made some more cookies. It worked really well. So if you could make a totoro cookie cutter that comes in two pieces, the outline and the imprint, I would love that. Another request if you have time to modify the current design, is for you to make the pupils stronger (thicker). I used the smallest size bristle I had to clean the dough out that was stuck in the eye sockets, and the stick that prints the pupils broke in both eyes. So I guess next time, I'll use a toothpick to punch pupils in the eyes.
Do you think my problems have to do with the kind of plastic (transparent) the printer used (at the public library)? The blue plastic in the photo you provided looks much thicker and sturdier, I don't see two separate layers for the outline, and the pupil sticks look thicker and less breakable, too.
Thank you!
comments.author: TechDante

comments.text: Hi, I tried removing some layers, but the strips kept breaking, and it took time to get the cookie cutter edge level. Because there are two layers, you have to cut the outer layer first, then the inner. Because I was afraid of hurting myself, the plastic is stiff and slippery against the cutter blade, in the end, I only trimmed a few mm. I tried making cookies again yesterday, and the new height was a pretty good improvement. Thank you for the suggestion. Also, it's winter now, so the dough was stiffer, and releasing the dough was much less of a problem. This time, I didn't have to reknead and reflatten the dough so many times to get good imprints. I'm not going to post the current height, though; because maybe as you say, it's a matter of preference. However, I've decided that to save myself time in the future, to completely take the trial and error out, i.e, so it will work no matter what thickness I roll the dough out, I'm going to attempt to separate the silhouette of the Totoro from the imprint part. I might use a soldering iron, although it will ruin the aesthetic appeal of the cookie cutter, because I just made a gash in my new wooden table top with the cutter when it slipped.  :(
comments.author: TechDante

comments.text: Did you ever make a cookie with this?  Add a photo! I'm sure Totoro fans would like to see it :)

title: The Object

description.text:
Forget ePay and bootleggers, bring "The Object" into your home via 3D printing and have all the mashup magic of Kubrick/Page/Plant at your next dinner! "The Object" is a an enigmatic sculpture by legendary design group Hipgnosis http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hipgnosis, featured on the "Presence" http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presence_(album) album. The original was painted into photographs, then an actual object was created and photographed for the back cover and promotional materials. More on its history: http://zeppelincollectables.com/pages.php?pageid=4 In addition to two version of The Object, the DXF files of the band member's symbols are included for use in mashups. "To seek the man whose pointing hand, The giant step unfolds
To guide us from the curving path, That churns up into stone" http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p6S9oqJRclo

http://vimeo.com/24024599
  • Scale and print with or without the four symbols
  • Invite it to a fancy harbor-side dinner...

author: TeamTeamUSA

description.text:
my dog likes to pick up her bowls and bring them to me -- spilling everything in the process  
made this for 1/4 inch material (635mm)
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:340321 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=340321

Using the following options: BlockLength = 5
Name = KAT
BlockWidth = 2

Hi there! To print this spool holder I'd advise you to print in ABS, XT or other materials, that can be drilled. I've used Colorfabb clear XT. The spools are specially made for my Colorfabb spools (200mm OD, 55mm thickness), but most spools will work. What you need: Spool_Holder_Base printed twice Spool_Holder_Arm printed once 8 M5x20 or similar length, no less then 15, no more then 30! Preferably countersunk, but all heads work. ~25cm of rod, OD 6mm, ID 4mm, preferably metal (aluminium) e3d Bowden coupling http://e3d-online.com/Mechanical/Bowden/Bowden-Adaptor-1.75mm-Filament 4 ball bearings 625ZZ 5mm drill (if possible also 5,5mm)
6mm drill (if possible also 6,5mm)
12mm drill (up to 13mm is fine too, but at least 12mm)
drill for countersinking (if you use countersunk screws)
M5 tab, if possible also some cutting fluid Assembly of the base: Take both printed bases and drill in the holes with a 5mm drill, to get a good bore, you can also use 5,5mm drills, which will make the assembly a little bit easier, but don't drill too wide holes.
If you use countersunk screws you should also sink the holes accordingly. Make sure to sink the flat side of the Bases, there is a little ring sticking out of one side of the bore, do not remove it ! Take the rod and cut them to the following lengths:
2x 47mm
2x 59mm Drill M5 threads in all sides of the aluminium rods. Take the Spool_Holder_Arm and drill 6mm holes in the two exsisting holes, due to 3d printing the holes might be too narrow. To ensure easy fitting you can also use a 6,5mm drill.
After that you have to drill the open bore at the end of the arm with a 12mm drill, I've first used a 12mm one, then 13mm to loosen the snapfit a little bit. Take 4 screws and push them through the holes of one base, the heads are on the flat side of the base. Take the 59mm long rods and screw them onto the lower screws.
Take the ball bearings and put them on the thread of the upper screws, now screw on the 47mm long rods against the bearings.
Before proceeding similar with the second base, you first have to push on the Spool_Holder_Arm on one side of the rods.
After that you can screw on the second base to the rods and tighten everything. Your spools should now drop easily onto the spools and should spin freely, the filament can be inserted in a bowden tube, which is held in place with a snap-fitting bowden addapter. If the spool as too much play along it's spinning axis (too wide spool holder), you have to remove one base and take a file to shorten the rods, this is only necessary, if the clearance between the spool and the bases is so large, that the spool might fall off of the bearings. To hold the arm in place you can use the small holes to drill through the arm and the aluminium rod, after that you can taper the alumnium rod and screw in a M3 screw. My arm fits neatly on the aluminium rods and there was no need to use those screws for me. To use this spool holder for smaller or larger spools, you have to adjust the rods length, make sure to have the smaller ones allways 12mm shorter, then the longer ones, to compensate for the bearings and the spacer on the bases. If you need more information, feel free to comment.

description.text: PAC-MAN model with a built in stand and the PAC-MAN logo on the base. Printed on a DeltaMaker using DeltaMaker Neon Yellow PLA Filament.

This is the original Printrbot design modified to mount on Slotted Steel Angle Stock with 5/16" bolts. This design is moved to https://www.youmagine.com/designs/printrbot-bits You can box in the smooth Z rods and create any kind of a rigid frame you want. Its a fun and inexpensive way to build a large 3D printer. I'm sure there are physical limits to the size and shape you can build but this platform gives you a lot of flexibility - its up to you to build, explore, learn, and have fun.
I'm not providing build instructions for this bot - its not a kit - nor am I claiming this will build a better bot that anything already on the market. This is for our Maker club and it is up to up you to figure it out and learn along the way - its half the fun I promise. Parts are labeled but you will have to decide how you want to arrange the outer frame. A good resource would be the original printrbot configuration on youtube. https://youtu.be/6swI8Mer_yw

This is a universial ball and socket joint. The grove around the edge of the socket is for an o-ring [ OD = 1-7/16" ID = 1-5/16" WALL 1/16" ] designed in order to keep the ball from coming out. This part is apart of a project for Humboldt State University ENGR 215 and was design for SCRAP Humboldt. Please visit this page if you are courious what it was used for. (http://www.appropedia.org/SCRAP_Humboldt_carpet_samples_dry_mop)

author: VCIS

description.text: something i whipped up just for fun. If anyone out there makes this, please let me know what you think of it, that would be greatly appreciated.

I made these simple LED light diffusers for 3mm and 5mm LEDs.  
No glue is needed, just push the diffusers onto the LEDs, and they should fit snugly enough not to fall off.  
I suggest printing in transparent PLA/ABS, but I guess nice effects can be achieved with other colors as well, even if not transparent. For my project, I needed them to be transparent.  
The last photo shows the project I made them for, a 4x4x4 touch screen controlled LED cube.

Print with 0.2mm layers, better on a raft, given the very tiny footprint the diffusers have.  
I suggest transparent PLA filament.

Instead of throwing away (big pack) tic-tac containers, use them to store little things... like bolts and nuts!
This parametric script will generate a holder so you can hang the containers on a pegboard, or stand them up on a table.

Modify the script to hold the number of containers you prefer. (With "big pack" containers, the biggest is 4x1 for a ToM HBP.) The script can generate:
  • a basic holder
  • a holder with 1" separation hanging mount holes (i.e. to hang on pegboard hooks)
  • a stand to glue to the holder, so it can free-stand on a table
    • Updates:
  • 2011-05-25 -- Uploaded better stand; this one is wider and longer, so it's easier to glue on, and won't tip over as easily with a full load.

title: Openbuilds v-slot X axis for Lulzbot TAZ 4 or 5 printers or the AO-10X ballscrew modification

description.text:
This project adds a bolt on, no firmware modification required fully supported X axis to the Lulzbot Taz 4 and 5 printers in place of the existing bearing rod. Build thread is here:
https://forum.lulzbot.com/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=2252 Video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IsBAXx0Zjm0 installation manual is in the works, don't expect it for a few days though. Edit: the original printed backplate had an error, and was too tall. The new one has been corrected. You will want to print the new one. The CNC version is fine as is. Edit 2: Uploaded new endcaps and idler tensioner. These parts are compatable with the existing part set. They fix minor geometry issues, add capacity for an X maximum endstop, and move the Idler tensioner bolts out far enough that the tension can be adjusted while the entire rail is mounted on the machine. You do not need to print and install these parts unless you wish to incorporate the additional features to your build. The older parts have been left as a conveniance to anyone wishing to reprint that style. Edit 3: The instructions PDF is now uploaded! Yay! Edit 4: A huge thank you to Tom Swanson (http://www.thingiverse.com/Tomscables/about) who assembled and created the An assembly document that includes an exploded assembly view and a much nicer tabulated bill of materials. Open source community helping grow and refine Open Source designs, it's what it's all about. You can view the new document in the uploaded files:
Final_x_axis_Assembly_Diagram_Exploded_view_v1_11_17_2016.pdf (It is definitely worth taking a look at the picture assembly document as well still) Edit 5: I have a limited number of the metal backplates available for sale, $25 shipped via USPS to a domestic U.S. address. if you happen to want one, please feel free to send me a message here and we can go over logistics. The printed backplate is adequate for making this work, the metal one is more compact than the printed one, and will fit such things as the cable chain anchors and the bed leveling probe mount.

I'll update these instructions more when i get the X carriage itself finished, but for now you will need some M5 heatset inserts, some of the longer M3 heat set inserts (mcmaster carr is a good source for those) assorted M5 and M3 bolts, M5 T-nuts for the openrail, and the following openrail parts: 1 60mm x 20mm Openbuilds linear extrusion 500mm long extrusion, Manually remove 64mm. http://openbuildspartstore.com/black-v-slot-linear-rail/
4 sets of bearing wheels (http://openbuildspartstore.com/xtreme-solid-v-wheel-kit/ or other sets) ,
2 spacers (6mm probably) http://openbuildspartstore.com/aluminum-spacers/
2 eccentric spacers http://openbuildspartstore.com/eccentric-spacer/
one of their Gantry mounting plates. http://openbuildspartstore.com/v-slot-gantry-plates/
Bolts and nuts (M5, 30mm.) You will need to cut 64mm off of the openbuild rail. The cut end will be inside the end piece and will not need to be increadibly precise. A standard hacksaw cut will do fine. This will give you a 5mm adjustment gap to be able to move the endcaps in or out as allignment of your printer requires. Updated part list: X motor mount
4x 10mm M5
6x M5 11mm Long Heat set inserts (Mcmaster carr )
4x M5 T slot nuts X motor mount plate
10mm M5 bolts 6x
12mm M3 4x bolts Left X end
10mm M5 1x
20mm M5 x2
Stock 3 M5 Bolts and washers for Endplate connections 3 M5 T nuts
2 m2 bolts for endstop, 10mm thread Right X end
10mm M5 1x
20mm M5 x2
Stock 3 M5 Bolts and washers for Endplate connections
3 6.75mm long M5 Heat set inserts
3 M5 T nuts X idler mount
Stock Lulzbot idler bearings, washers, Nut and large bolt
2 6.75mm long M5 Heat set inserts
2 M5 32mm bolts (the idler adjusters
2 10mm M5 bolts
2 M5 Tslot nuts X Carriage adaptor plate
4x M3 8mm bolts
11 M3 heat set inserts (the short 3mm-4mm ones)
Stock Lulzbot V notch plastic piece. Stock 4 bolts and washers that hold down that piece (M3 10mm thread plus M3 washers)
The stock Lulzbot carriage hold down bolt and washer (M3 washer M3 bolt 10mm thread) Backplate
One 35mm long M5 Flat head bolt and Nut (for lower middle Carriage hole )
One 1/4" bolt that fits the larger eccentric holes, also about 35mm long and nut (for top backplate hole)
Spacers and washers to space out middle section of backplate. i ended up using 2x 6mm spacers, a 9mm spacer and a bunch of washers on the top and bottom. this could probably be a printed part. The one at the top is the critical one.
Belt mount posts are made of:
2x 1/8" bolt, 1 inch or so long
4x 1/8" nuts
2x 1/8" threaded plastic spacers wide enough to hold a bolt
2x large-ish washers bigger than the plastic spacers to keep the bolt slipping off the end Openrails parts: 1 60mm x 20mm Openbuilds linear extrusion 500mm long extrusion, Manually remove 64mm. http://openbuildspartstore.com/black-v-slot-linear-rail/
4 sets of bearing wheels (http://openbuildspartstore.com/xtreme-solid-v-wheel-kit/ or other sets) ,
6 spacers (6mm ) http://openbuildspartstore.com/aluminum-spacers/
2 eccentric spacers also 6mm http://openbuildspartstore.com/eccentric-spacer/
one of their Gantry mounting plates. http://openbuildspartstore.com/v-slot-gantry-plates/
Flat head M5 Bolts and nuts 30mm (standard bolts will not fit, need the flat ones. ).
One 35mm long M5 Flat head bolt and Nut for lower middle Carriage hole
One 1/4" bolt that fits the larger eccentric holes, also about 35mm long and nut
Spacers and washers to space out middle section of backplate. i ended up using 2x 6mm spacers, a 9mm spacer and a bunch of washers on the top and bottom. this could probably be a printed part. The one at the top is the critical one. The backplate posts are currently made of 2x 1/8" bolts with flat heads, 2 nuts, 2 washers, 2 1/2" long threaded spacers, 2 washers and 2 more nuts. An alternative less mass configuration would also work here.

comments.text: The Taz6 X to Z axis geometry is slightly different. It lacks the X end plates, and moves the bearing guide rod closer to the leadscrew. There is a taz 6 specific end piece, but it is currently undergoing revision and doesn't fit without modification. I'm working on it, but its been a lower priority than some of the other projects https://forum.lulzbot.com/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=4908
comments.author: AndreTT

comments.text:
The PDF instructions sizes for M5 Bolts seems to be in error generally.
There are a few places where it lists a size ending in a 2 (ie 32) when I believe they were meant to in a 5 (ie 35); but it was done several times.
And there were a lot of 10mm M5 listed but in most cases these are not long enough to fit through the part and provide enough threads to grip (or in most cases they just were flush with the other side). When replaced with a 15mm M5 it would function. This was annoying since I ordered 10mm in quantity and end up only uses one or two and didn't order enough 15mm. There were a few others that were also short but I happened to have some of them and they were just one or two of those.

comments.author: piercet

comments.text: I measured all the bolts as I was assembling, the measurements reflect the required bolt thread length, not the overall bolt thread length. The  two 32mm long bolts for the idler tensioner are correct. The longer bolts for the backplate with a metal backplate should either be 35mm or 30mm long for the most part. The 10mm long bolts worked fine for the T-nuts and parts as printed on this end, I just pulled one to measure. Maybe they sent you the wrong bolts? I'm sorry that you were annoyed by that, it wasn't my intention to annoy you. The small spacer is designed to be threaded onto the M5 bolt to provide extra support, you can certanly also drill it without affecting it at all, and if a printer is overextruding the hole diameter may quite possibly be too small. They print fine on mine anyways. At any rate, sorry you wncountered difficulties.
comments.author: Makuna

comments.text: I measured them, 10mm was not long enough.
comments.author: piercet

comments.text: I print with Repetier host using my own custom slicer ABS profile for a 0.5mm nozzle. No scaling, printed in ABS. Are you getting a raised lip around the holes by any chance? that could account for it. Not sure what to tell you otherwise heh.
comments.author: Makuna

comments.text: The instructions were pretty confusing around the carriage due to the assumptions of a metal plate.
comments.author: Makuna

comments.text:
If you use the printed T Bracket, there are a few things you need to do that are listed in the instructions to make it work.
1) The bolts that hold the belt studs, omit the nut between the bracket and the first carriage washer. The T Bracket is already thick and this extra nut will put the belt studs way offset out of the plane of the belt causing the zip ties on the belt to collide with the end pieces.
2) Due to normal printing tolerances, the inside of the T bracket will need some trimming to reach the full extension on the X axis. This area where the T bracket slides next to the end stops has a very close tolerance. You can test it by just moving the X axis all the way to each end. I had to also make sure the lock nut was aligned so an edge was parallel to the end stop edges, otherwise it would collide.
comments.author: Makuna

comments.text: flat side of the printed T bracket goes towards the rail, or towards the front carriage.
comments.author: Makuna

comments.text: The longer m5 heat set inserts are usually narrower than the short ones for some reason. You will need a deeper 0.3mm narrower hole to fully engage. You can try a couple of things. If you mush the last 3mm of the longer insert into the shorter hole, it may melt enough plastic to lock it in place. You can also try printing a thin plastic insert ring and melt locking it in place. Another option would be tape over both ends of the insert, put it in the hole with epoxy, then let 7t cure and remove the upper tape, hopefully preserving the threads. If you go that route you might want to consider gluing it in upside down to lock it into the bore.
comments.author: piercet

comments.text: I can get the longer M5 inserts to fit by filing them with a metal file and making plastic "rings" to melt them in place with, works great, thanks!
comments.author: piercet

comments.text: I intended  the printed backplate  to get a bolt through it with a nut securing it in place. I have seen people use the heat set inserts too though. Either way works fine.
comments.author: ategro

comments.text: Just to be sure - using your intended method means drilling through the holes, right? Cheers, excited to implement this mod
comments.author: piercet

comments.text: Yeah, in some cases the only way to get a clean hole is to force a bridging operation that needs to get drilled out later. Those are one of those places.

It's as if it's too short in both ends even though the rail is the correct size and the idler endpiece is positioned about 5mm away from the rail. Any ideas? :) Thanks. Also, do you know if the Mcmaster Carr heat set inserts are available somewhere else? Installing these narrower ones the way I've done it is not very stable, but I can't seem to find anything in Europe that will fit.

One of the Lulzbot forum users was able to find them in Germany using the information in this post https://forum.lulzbot.com/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=2897&p=26813&hilit=heat+set+inserts#p26813

title: Game Boy Battery Cover (for Original Game Boy)

description.text: Replacement battery cover for the original 1989 Nintendo Game Boy. The tolerances for getting this to work properly are extremely low; the battery cover needs to fit perfectly in order to snap into place properly, and align with the edges of the Game Boy. Since not all 3D printers print the same model exactly the same, I've included the .scad file, so you can make adjustments in case the cover printed by your printer doesn't fit your Game Boy correctly. OpenSCAD file requires http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8812

title: 3D Star Trek Chess Set | Revolution Remix Edition

description.text:
3D Star Trek Chess Set remixed to provide a see through experience for the benefit of 3D play (i.e. looking through the board at the squares directly underneath) The command and science keys are the black and white tiles, (Thinking of Kirk and Spock). This open concept design instead of solid platforms also reduces overall print material. Note that the board works with the original separate printed part tiles, if you wish to use them. Personally I like the full see through. :) I have included the files for the tiles and all other printed pars from the original design. This design is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:214463 Check there for instructions and game info. All files are listed here. I am designing new chess pieces now and will post them when done. The Badges are from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:307396
and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:66187 I will post pictures of all printed parts as they are completed.

title: X-idler Mount Plate and related parts for Makerfarm i3v 10"

description.text:
There is a newer version of this design that has an idler assembly that allows you to adjust the tension on the X-axis belt on the idler side. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:878023 This is a plastic version of the Makerfarm i3v 10" X-idler wooden plate. It is probably the same plate for the 8" & 12" version. There is a 3 wheel and a 4 wheel version. The eccentric spacer holes are countersunk, so you do not need a washer where the lock nut attaches. I personally put a washer between the locknut & the plastic. I am waiting on some new wheels before changing this on my printer. My print time for 3 wheel version took 01:12:23 to print & used 765oz of PTEG plastic at .6 infill. I also included plastic replacements of the idler mount plate & Z-Limit Screw plate. I used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:795954 for the connection to the Z-axis threaded rod instead of the original wooden part.
If you use the wooden part, you will most likely need to do some filing on the rectangle hole. I also noticed it was a rather tight fit with that wooden part next to the Top wheel nut. One other change I might make later on this part is instead of having a hole where the idler pulley bolt goes thru, make that a slot to allow for an extra spot to adjust the belt tension. First test print of new design seems like it will work. Will test fit early this week & update this if it works good.

For the main 3 wheel plate print one these parts:
i3v_X-IdlerMount_3Wheel_WithEars_rev9.stl
i3v_X-IdlerMount_3Wheel_NoEars_rev9.stl
i3v_X-IdlerMount_3Wheel_rev9.scad (or edit this file to your liking) If you want to try this with 4 wheels instead of the stock 3 wheels, print one of these:
i3v_X-IdlerMount_4Wheel_WithEars_rev9.stl
i3v_X-IdlerMount_4Wheel_NoEars_rev9.stl
i3v_X-IdlerMount_4Wheel_rev9.scad (or edit this file to your liking) Remove any of the extra plastic from the wheel holes by hand turning a 5/16" bit for the eccentric countersunk holes
& 3/16" bit for the M5 bolts that go on the wheels. I would also print http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:795954 that connects to the Z-axis threaded rod instead of using the stock wooden part. I am not sure how well that original wooden part will fit with this plastic version. The other plastic parts related to this you can change from wood to plastic are:
X-IdlerPulley_repaired.stl
X-IdlerPulley.scad (or edit this file) Some people are probably using something different than this original method for the Z-Limit Switch, but I am still using this.
ZLimitScrewPlate_rev2_repaired.stl
ZLimitScrewPlate_rev2.scad Build thread for this design: http://3dprintboard.com/showthread.php?13185-Plastic-X-Idler-Plate-to-replace-Wood-Parts

4" long cable holder for Apple Lightening cables, Micro USB etc. it has 5 slots that can be used.

Works in progress. This is still in beta stage and a lot of things will change. You are looking at a Hexacopter with motor to motor distance of ~ 760 mm. It was designed from scratch in Sketchup and the frame was 3D printed on Ultimaker2 with ColorFabb's PLA filament. Word of Warning:
Multirotors are extremely dangerous flying machines. Their propellers are like knives and rotate several hundred rotations per minute. Especially Hexacopter like this one. It can cause severe injury and bleeding in a fraction of a second! Do not fly it close to humans. You need to know what you are doing when you fly a multirotor. Respect the airspace where you fly, it is not allowed to fly in the CTR without a special permission from respective Airport. Neither I or this project is NOT responsible for your actions. Feel free to ask questions in the comments or PM. I will be glad to answer those related to 3D model, Sketchup and this particular build. There are both STL and source Sketchup files uploaded on this thing so you are free to modify it your needs as you wish. Now let's jump to the next section and look at the instructions :)

For GPS Holder:
Use this model http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:833513 and replace its Omnimac_3DR_Aerodynamic_GPS_Stalk_boom_top.stl with the "Adapter for Aerodynamic GPS Holder" from this thing. This is in order to mount on the top plate. Omnimac_3DR_Aerodynamic_GPS_Stalk_boom_bottom.stl is not needed. Pin is used to mount it top GPS part with the bottom one.

title: Cupcake Gen3 Extruder Controller, Relay Board and Stepper Driver Mount

description.text: This is for mounting three boards -- such as the EC, relay, and extruder stepper driver boards -- to the side of a cupcake. It replaces my "Cupcake Gen3 Extruder Controller and Relay Board Mount" ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6780 ), adding a mounting point for a fourth stepper driver for the extruder (or another board of comparable size, because it is fully parametric).

This part is beefier than the previous one because the boards stick out farther from the mounting point, and is designed to be used with 14mm screws, though you can probably get away with anything from 12-15mm with the included STL, or modify the thickness parameter in the scad file to accomodate other sizes.

author: port2starboard

description.text:
Simple Flashlight, just need one 3mm Straw Hat White LED Lamp Light Emitting 3V DC Diode and one 3V button cell "CR2016L". They are available at Amazon.  
NO SOLDERING! Easy to assemble.

This has a lot of critical tolerances.
1.) Clean print.
2.) The shorter wire of the diode is negative. Trim that so it fits in the recess on the bottom half of the case.
3.) Trim the other positive lead so it 1/8th of an inch past the center of the battery.
4.) Add the button battery (CR2016L) between the two leads with the positive side facing up. Push battery into case recess.
5.) Position the leads of the diode so they are perpendicular to the case and add a small drop of superglue to the head of the diode. Hold firmly in place with needle nose pliers until glue sets.
6.) Add a small piece of tape to the end of the battery so the positive lead of the diode does not make contact with the edge of the battery.
7.) Ream holes so they are larger. (Just enough to allow the posts from the other side to snugly fit. If you ream too much the posts will not lock in place.)
8.) Snap the sides of the case together. Note: If you want a tighter fit with no seams, you can glue seams and use pliers to clamp edge of sides tight. (Glue and clamp just the outer edges. DO NOT glue and clamp near the center of the case.)

description.text: Here is a relief globe that includes the sea bottom. It was created using the program "globe" by DJ Moews available under the GNU GENERAL PUBLIC LICENSE. Globe can be downloaded from http://djm.cc/dmoews.html. The data is derived from the Scripps SRTM30_PLUS V8.0 data set which is copyright but can be used for non-commercial purposes - see srtm30plus_copyright.txt for the license. The derived data set, srtm30plus, the input to globe, is at http://djm.cc/dmoews.html. Two stl files are provided: n_hemisphere.stl and s_hemisphere.stl When printed and joined together the two files produce a globe about 5 inches in diameter. The red version in the image above was scaled by 0.8.

The input command for globe was: globe --map altitude data/srtm30plus 5400 2700 sbigendiandibyte --gridpoints 512 --map-scale 60 --cut-plane 0 0 1 --explode 1000000 >bigz.stl.  The two pieces of the globe were separated, centered, and scaled to give n_hemisphere.stl and s_hemisphere.stl.  
On my Replicator I used two shells and 2% infill and printed the files directly on the build platform.  This minimizes warping and the two halves join at the equator with a nearly invisible seam.  
Program globe can output the globe in multiple pieces and a 6 inch globe was constructed using 4 pieces.  It was not fully successful because of ABS warping at the thin edges.  If planes 1 0 0 and 0 1 0 are used for cutting warping imperfections are collected at the poles.  A 6 inch globe takes over 20 hours to print.

title: Aluminium Arms Z-Axis Upgrade - Makes your Makerbot Replicator 2 and 2x a real tool

description.text:
IDE Aluminium upgrade Z axis for MakerBot Replicator 2&2X - Make your Replicator a real tool! What are the benefits? The IDE Z axis upgarde increases print quality significantly cause of literally no vibrations - our customers tell us that they never had comparable results before. It saves time and money - does not bend or warp during the use, so you do not have to level your build plate again and again anymore. Once leveled you are done. It replaces the aluminium guides with hardened steel guides so it is backlash free (in all directions) cause of the use of linear ball bearings, what prevents a tilt / stutter during the Z-axis motion. The dials for the leveling of the build platform are large and easy to grip and also self-locking and can not therefore twist while printing. The firmware or MakerWare has not to be manipulated, all axis traveling stays the same, so you can print directly after the conversion again. Who will like to use it? We have professional users like Bosch,Volkswagen, Airbus and many other huge companies, as well as universities, schools, small businesses and private users. So in fact everyone with a MakerBot Replicator 2 or 2X will love the improvements that our upgrade brings. You will see quality improvements as well as more comfort and less maintenance. A weak point of the MakerBot Replicator 2 and 2X is the complete Z-axis design. This is made of plastic and of many individual parts. The bearing can not be adjusted / aligned and the complete construction is very soft and tends to oscillate. Of course this is totally counterproductive for the printing quality. Is it complicated to install? Not at all! The installation is really as easy as playing lego, we ship it with a detailed, pictured assembly guide and really everyone can install it in just a few minutes. Its easy to install and you do not have to modifications on existing parts of your printer. (also see the video further down). Conversion time:
about 30 minutes, doable for everyone without special knowledge. What is part of the offer?
Complete upgrade kit for the Z-axis, linear bearings, CNC machined aluminum plate, screws and small parts
Detailed, illustrated conversion instructions. The set can be built out again and the Replicator 2 / 2X can be restored to the factory settings at any time, at the original parts nothing is changed/modified.
The Z-Axis is compatible with the original Replicator 2&2X Buildplates and of course with our Upgrade-Heated-Buildplate 100% made in Germany! Video from one of our satisfied customers, who upgraded Z axis and heated build plate
https://youtu.be/DaNQwpoWbQs you can find and order the whole set here (shipping from Germany worldwide)
http://www.ebay.com/itm/IDE-Makerbot-Replicator-2-2X-alumunium-Z-Axis-upgrade-Made-in-Germany-/352122376187?epid=879488530&hash=item51fc210ffb:g:ObEAAOSw8oFXzcNS or directly over the webshop https://www.ide-3d.de: https://www.ide-3d.de/epages/83488941.sf/en_US/?ObjectPath=/Shops/83488941/Products/MKBz

You can order the whole Set on eBay:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/IDE-Makerbot-Replicator-2-2X-alumunium-Z-Axis-upgrade-Made-in-Germany-/352122376187?epid=879488530&hash=item51fc210ffb:g:ObEAAOSw8oFXzcNS or directly over the webshop https://www.ide-3d.de: https://www.ide-3d.de/epages/83488941.sf/en_US/?ObjectPath=/Shops/83488941/Products/MKBz The printable parts are included in the set. author: Lauro_Antico

description.text: A SketchUp model I did a few years ago and decided to print for my own pleasure and for promotion material. I printed it on the ORD MH3000 in our Sensorica Lab, with BambooFill on 0.5mm nozzle and sliced at 0.3mm with Cura. The roof has 4 support walls to be removed after printing and there's a little floor (grenier du haut) to be glued under the roof carefully. Enjoy!

Created to fundraise for the Zooplankton Project. See more info here: http://www.zooplanktonproject.com/ This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0k976XbEMDK

These dice are a fun way for my students explore probability. If you look closely at them, you will notice that these are not your normal dice. One has the numbers 1, 2, 2, 3, 3, and 4. The other has 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 8. These are Sicherman Dice. What makes them interesting is that despite their mixed up appearance, the probabilities for rolling various totals is the same as a regular pair of dice! You can go to http://www.cut-the-knot.org/arithmetic/combinatorics/Sicherman.shtml for a more detailed description of these mathematical oddities. (The stl files are for 1 inch dice, but can be resized to fit your needs.)
